The '''2012 Paros beating and rape''' of a teenage girl by an [[Illegal immigration|illegal immigrant]] named Ahmed Waqas (alternate names reported including Ahmet Vaka, Ahmet Bakas, and Ahmet Vakash){{cite news|last1=Tsiliopoulos |first1=E. |title=Omogeneia Rushes to Aid Myrto |url=http://www.newgreektv.com/index.php/omogeneia/item/1710-omogeneia-rushes-to-aid-myrto |accessdate=14 September 2015 |publisher=[[New Greek TV]] |date=13 November 2013 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813162959/http://www.newgreektv.com/index.php/omogeneia/item/1710-omogeneia-rushes-to-aid-myrto |archivedate=13 August 2014 }} attracted widespread attention. Perpetrated on the island of [[Paros]], [[Greece]], the case became notorious at a time of rising concern about the increasing numbers of illegal immigrants arriving in the country. Injuries to the victim, usually referred to in the Greek press solely by her first name "Myrto" ({{lang-el|Μυρτώ}}), resulted in permanent [[disability]]. == The event == On 23 July 2012 a teenage girl, Myrto Papadomichelaki ({{lang-el|Μυρτώ Παπαδομιχελάκη}}), was found half naked, beaten and in a coma, on one of the most popular beaches in the Greek island, [[Paros]]. Her head had been bashed in with a rock weighing 5 kilos.{{cite news|last1=Labropoulos|first1=Vasilis|title=Δράκος της Πάρου: "Της έλιωσα το κεφάλι με μια πέτρα πέντε κιλών"|url=http://www.tovima.gr/society/article/?aid=470059|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=Tovima|date=7 August 2012}} The authorities ordered the girl to be transferred to a hospital in [[Athens]] so that she would have the best of care and started looking for evidence in the [[crime scene]] in order to find the assaulter.,Gr Reporter, (2012). 15-year-old tourist on Paros Island beaten and probably raped. Retrieved from: http://www.grreporter.info/en/15yearold_tourist_paros_island_beaten_and_probably_raped/7415.{{cite news|title=Die Urlaubsinsel Paros und die Kykladenmafia|url=http://www.heise.de/tp/artikel/37/37456/1.html|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=Heise|date=17 August 2012}} At first, police investigated the incident as an accident. However, when the [[forensic]] specialist from Athens, Dr. Nikos Kalogrias announced that he had found semen over the girl’s body, the focus of the investigation changed to rape and near-fatal beating.{{cite news|title=So wurde ein illegaler Einwanderer zum Vergewaltiger von Paros|url=http://www.unzensuriert.at/content/009883-So-wurde-ein-illegaler-Einwanderer-zum-Vergewaltiger-von-Paros|accessdate=26 July 2015|date=1 September 2012}} == Suspects == According to the police report, initially the suspects were 12 men, Greeks and foreigners, who either worked by the beach and the crime scene or had been seen by witnesses in the area. As the investigation continued, the suspects were narrowed to four and police concluded, with the help of several eyewitnesses, that the suspect was a man who worked by the crime scene.,Gr Reporter, (2012). 21-year-old Pakistani sought for the brutal rape in Paros. Retrieved from: http://www.grreporter.info/en/21-year-old_pakistani_sought_brutal_rape_paros/7424. Specifically the mother of the teenage girl reported that she saw a man, wearing white trousers and a colorful shirt, walking away from the crime scene. Ahmed Waqas's co-workers said that he was wearing this kind of clothes at work the day of the incident. However, Ahmed had already left the island to go to Athens, ostensibly because of the serious illness of one of his relatives. Ahmed was picked up during a random check in Athens and DNA was used to identify him as the likely culprit.{{cite news|title=Man arrested in connection to brutal rape of teen|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/143667/article/ekathimerini/news/man-arrested-in-connection-to-brutal-rape-of-teen|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=Kathimerini|date=4 August 2012}} A gardener, Ahmed had told his Paros employers that he had to leave the island to visit an ailing family member.{{cite news|title=Police question suspect over brutal attack on Paros|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/143638/article/ekathimerini/news/police-question-suspect-over-brutal-attack-on-paros|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=Kathimerini|date=3 August 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Βασίλης|first1=Λαμπρόπουλος Βασίλης|title=Ποιος είναι ο "Δράκος της Χρυσής Ακτής"|url=http://www.tovima.gr/society/article/?aid=469740|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=To Vima|date=5 August 2012}} == Perpetrator == A few days later the police arrested Ahmed Waqas, in Nea Chalkidona, Athens, along with two other [[illegal immigrants]]. Police located suspect through his mobile phone and with the help of other immigrants., Keep Talking Greece, (2012). Paros: Police Arrests Assaulter of Teenager Girl; Illegal Immigrant from Pakistan Confesses the Crime. Retrieved from: http://www.keeptalkinggreece.com/2012/08/04/paros-police-arrests-assaulter-of-teenager-girl-illegal-immigrant-from-pakistan-confesses-the-crime/. The police compared DNA obtained from Ahmed's saliva with DNA that found on the girl's clothes and body and confirmed a match, after which Ahmed confessed his crime. Ahmed Waqas was reportedly calm and emotionless while describing the events of the crime to the police officers. As he stated, his first intention was to steal the girl's mobile phone but she tried to repel his attack. Then, he started beating her with a rock until she fell unconscious. While the girl could not fight anymore he raped her and then beat her again against the stones.{{cite news|last1=Διονύσης|first1=Βυθούλκας|title=Κρίθηκε προφυλακιστέος ο 19χρονος Πακιστανός για την κακοποίηση της 15χρονης|url=http://www.tovima.gr/society/article/?aid=469828|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=To Vima|date=6 August 2012}} The perpetrator had been scheduled for voluntary repatriation to Pakistan at the time of the arrest.{{cite news|title=Paros rape suspect was due for deportation, says police|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/143701/article/ekathimerini/news/paros-rape-suspect-was-due-for-deportation-says-police|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=[[Kathimerini]]|date=6 August 2012}} == Social reaction == After his confession, Ahmed Waqas was taken to the island of [[Syros]] where he testified again before the district prosecutor. While the police accompanied him from the ferry to the prosecutor's office, passersby shouted slogans against him. Supporters of the Greek nationalist party, [[Golden Dawn (party)|Golden Dawn]] were in the angry crowd shouting denunciations of the rapist., Gr Reporter, (2012). Rapist from Paros faces the prosecutor. Retrieved from: http://www.grreporter.info/en/rapist_paros_faces_prosecutor/7431. The political demonstrations that surrounded the transportation and trial of the perpetrator had a significant impact. Police, in fear of any reprisal actions, started an operation of localization of any illegal immigrants in down town Athens having as a goal the "cleaning" of the capital's center and the deportation of all illegals. Minister of Citizen Protection, [[Nikos Dendias]], stated that "the detention and deportation will continue until the center of Athens is "clean"", did not please the nationalist party, Golden Dawn which published the following announcement:
Enough with illegal immigrants! The horrible crime against a minor Greek was committed again by an illegal immigrant. The need for multiple deterrence measures is immediate. Any crime committed by an illegal alien must be statutory. Whoever talks about [[racism]], should host the criminals at his home. The only racism that exists, is the racism against the Greeks.
As suspect was being transported from Syros to the port of [[Piraeus]], near Athens, members of Golden Dawn, angered not only by the rape and attempted murder, but by the fact that the culprit appeared to have lied about his age to secure trial in the juvenile justice system, attempted to pull him from the police car in which he was being transported, allegedly in order to [[lynching|lynch]] him.{{cite news|title=The Pakistani raped calmly and consciously|url=http://www.grreporter.info/en/pakistani_raped_calmly_and_consciously/7440|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=Greek Reporter|date=8 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Greece: Police vehicle carrying Pakistani man attacked|url=http://www.euronews.com/2012/08/08/greece-police-vehicle-carrying-pakistani-man-attacked/|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=[[Euronews]]|date=8 August 2008}} After the initial trial, the perpetrator was discovered to have lied about his age in order to be tried and punished as a juvenile.{{cite news|title=Η Μυρτώ σε κρίσιμη κατάσταση - Ο πακιστανός συνεχίζει τις πολυτελείς διακοπές Διαβάστε περισσότερα|url=http://www.xryshaygh.com/enimerosi/view/h-murtw-se-krisimh-katastash-o-pakistanos-sunechizei-tis-poluteleis-diakope#.UZNN06Kmgvk|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=Xryshayg|date=15 May 2013}} == Trial == The defendant, an illegal immigrant, initially convinced authorities that he was a minor so that he could be adjudicated by a [[juvenile court]]. He first reported that he was born in 1991, then in 1993 and finally he stated that he was born in 1995. His inconsistency made the investigator ask the prosecutor to add those false statements to the prosecution. However Ahmed did not change his attitude and continued lying, as a result, the court's initial judgement was for him to be held in prison for two years.iNews, (2012). Αμετανόητος και προκλητικός ο πακιστανός ''δράκος'' της Πάρου!.. Η δύσκολη μάχη της 15χρονης για τη ζωή.... Retrieved from: http://www.inews.gr/135/ametanoitos-kai-proklitikos-o-pakistanos-drakos-tis-parou-i-dyskoli-machi-tis-15chronis-gia-ti-zoi.htm . The trial was a national news story in Greece.{{cite news|title=Trial to start over brutal 2012 attack on teenage girl in Paros|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/157340/article/ekathimerini/news/trial-to-start-over-brutal-2012-attack-on-teenage-girl-in-paros|accessdate=26 July 2015|publisher=[[Kathimerini]]|date=28 January 2014}} Perpetrator was sentenced to, "a life sentence for the robbery, 18 years in jail for the attempted homicide, 18 years in jail for the rape and three months in jail for illegal employment".{{cite news|title=Life sentence and 25 years jail for near-fatal assault and rape of teen girl Myrto|url=http://www.amna.gr/english/articleview.php?id=4903|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=ANAMPS.gr|date=28 January 2014}}{{cite news|title=Man gets life for brutal teen assault on Paros|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/157353/article/ekathimerini/news/man-gets-life-for-brutal-teen-assault-on-paros|accessdate=26 July 2015|publisher=[[Kathimerini]]|date=28 January 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Karathanou|first1=Helen|title=Τα ισόβια στο τέρας δεν έκλεισαν τις πληγές της Μυρτούς|url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/348282/eisaggeleas-exadlise-tin-ktinodia-tou-to-teras-tis-parou/|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=Protothema|date=28 January 2014}} An item in the online magazine ΠΑΡΑΔΡΑΣΗ condemned "treacherous and anti-Greek Leftwing" demonstrators who gathered outside the courthouse to protest on behalf of the rights of illegal immigrants.{{cite news|title=ΑΙΣΧΟΣ !! Next Edition |- |align="Center"| [[2015 FIA Hill Climb Masters]] |} The '''2014 FIA Hill Climb Masters''' was the first edition of [[FIA Hill Climb Masters]], between the winners of hill climb national championships, and the winners of the FIA Hill Climb Competitions. The event was held between 11–12 October 2014 in [[Eschdorf]], [[Luxembourg]].http://www.fia.com/news/hill-climb-latest-decisions-and-2014-calendars The overall win was taken by Frenchman Nicolas Schatz, at the wheel of his Category III [[Norma Auto Concept|Norma]], as he recorded a time of 48.344 seconds for the {{convert|1.85|km|mi|abbr=on}} run. He finished almost a quarter of a second clear of [[Scott Moran]], in his [[Gould Racing|Gould]], while the best of the Category II cars finished in third place with Eric Berguerand driving his [[Formula 3000]] [[Lola Racing Cars|Lola]]. The top Category I driver was Yanick Bodson, recording a time of 60.834 seconds. In the Nations' Cup, countries were ranked in their consistency; three drivers per nation were considered, with the gaps between a driver's two runs counting towards the rankings. Italy's gap of 3.182 seconds was the smallest and therefore won the Cup, beating Switzerland's gap of 3.463 seconds, while third place went to Austria, with their gap of 4.952 seconds. ==Results== http://www.rallycross-photo.com/heuvelklim/2014_uitslagen/141012_eschdorf.html ===Individual classification=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%" ! {{for|the band|Action Item}} In [[management]], an '''action item''' is a documented event, task, activity, or [[action (philosophy)|action]] that needs to take place. Action items are discrete units that can be handled by a single person.
==Planning actions== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2007}} Action items are usually created during a discussion by a group of people who are [[meeting]] about one or more topics and during the discussion it is discovered that some kind of action is needed. The act required is then documented as an action item and usually assigned to someone, usually a member of the group. The person to whom the action is assigned is then obligated to perform the action and report back to the group on the results.
Action items are usually documented in the meeting [[minutes]] and are recorded in the [[task list]] of the group. As people complete action items, the items are documented as being completed and the item is removed from the list of outstanding action items.
==Attributes== There are many attributes that can be associated with an action item - e.g.: * Identifier - Unique mark to reference event or item. * Description - Short explanation of activity to be performed * Work stream - Business requirements, technical design, user interface, commit checklist, commit gate materials, etc. (optional) * Issue or Risk - Associated with a project issue or risk * Status - Open, In Progress, Resolved, Canceled * Urgency/Priority - What is the impact to your project's critical path? * Comments - Description of what is now being done to solve the issue * Owner - Who is responsible for actively working the issue? * Created Date - Date issue was opened * Planned completion date - When will this issue be solved? * Actual completion date - Date issue was closed
==Tracking== {{Refimprove section|date=September 2007}} A usual format for an action item is to record an action item number, the date when the action item is identified or created, the name of the person to whom the action is assigned, a title description of the action, a more detailed description of the action and its outcomes, and its deliverables.
An action item can be considered a more general form of various types of action/issue/defect tracking methods. For instance, a [[bug report]] is a form of action item as is a service report created by a service company to track a problem reported by a customer or an [[Return Merchandise Authorization|RMA]] number.
Follow up in a consistent and timely manner with the responsible individual(s) to track their progress and drive the action item to resolution.
It is important to understand the distinction here that we track to resolution and not to completion. While it is the goal to have every action item completed, there are numerous scenarios in which the action item may no longer be relevant or completion may not be possible.
==Software==
There are a number of software applications for tracking action items or service reports. These applications are used within software development organizations as well as in customer support functions. Because these software applications facilitate group communication, they are often referred to as [[Collaborative software]] or groupware.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}. Various such software are available in the market. They are known to increase the productivity of Managers.
Many information technology support groups use some kind of service report software so that when a trouble report is called in, the person answering the telephone will create a trouble ticket to track the issue. The trouble ticket is assigned to a member of the IT services organization who then visits the person who has reported a problem and resolves the problem. The IT services person will then close out the trouble ticket indicating the issue has been resolved.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}
Recent research at the Computational Semantics Lab at [[Stanford University]] seeks to automatically identify action items and extract their properties (the ''what'', ''who'', and ''when'' of the action item) using [[automatic speech recognition]] transcripts from spontaneous, multi-party conversations during meetings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nlp.stanford.edu/pubs/sigdial06.pdf|title=Automatically Detecting Action Items in Audio Meeting Recordings|website=Stanford EDU|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} == See also == {{Wiktionary|action item}} * [[Task list]] * [[Bug report]] * [[IT Service Management]]

Algoraves!|url=http://www.arte.tv/fr/hacking-clubbing-algoraves/7769884,CmC=7768150.html|accessdate=10 November 2015|website=ARTE}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2006/07/real-djs-code-live/|title=Real DJs Code Live|website=Wired|accessdate=26 January 2016|last=Andrews|first=Robert}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|year=2004|title=Live coding in laptop performance|journal=Organised Sound|volume=Cambridge University Press|issue=3|pages=321–330|doi=10.1017/S135577180300030X|author=Collins, N.|author2=McLean, A.|author3=Rohrhuber, J.|author4=Ward, A.|last-author-amp=yes}}<!--|access-date=30 January 2016--> </ref> including for creating [[TidalCycles]], a live-coding environment<ref>{{cite web|last1=McLean|first1=Alex|title=Tidal – Pattern Language for Live Coding of Music|url=http://smcnetwork.org/node/1371|website=Sound and Music Computing|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> that allows programmer musicians to code simply and quickly,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bell|first1=Sarah|website=British Science Association|accessdate=9 November 2015|title=Live Coding Brings Programming to Life – an interview with Alex McLean|url=http://www.britishscienceassociation.org/blog/live-coding-brings-programming-to-life-an-interview-with-alex-mac}}</ref> and for coining the term [[Algorave]] with [[Nick Collins (composer)|Nick Collins]].<ref>{{Cite web | last = Cheshire |first = Tom |title = Hacking meets clubbing with the 'algorave' | work = Wired | date = 29 August 2013 | url = https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2013/09/play/algorave | accessdate = 29 August 2013}}</ref>
He is an active and influential member of the [[live coding]] community; he is a co-founder of TOPLAP<ref>{{cite web|title=Toplap Credits|url=http://smcnetwork.org/node/1371|website=Sound and Music Computing|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> and joint leader of the Live Coding Research Network.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Live Coding Research Network|url=http://www.livecodenetwork.org/about/}}</ref> Alex is co-founder of the Chordpunch record label<ref>{{cite web|title=Hacking + Clubbing = Algoraves!|url=http://www.arte.tv/fr/hacking-clubbing-algoraves/7769884,CmC=7768150.html|accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref>
McLean is also known for his work in [[software art]], winning the [[Transmediale]] award for software art in 2002 for ''forkbomb.pl'',<ref>{{Cite book|title = Community Without Community in Digital Culture|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xlA0K8yHOh4C|publisher = Palgrave Macmillan|date = 7 August 2012|isbn = 9781137026675|first = Charlie|last = Gere}}</ref> a short Perl script which creates a unique image from an operating system under heavy load,<ref>{{Cite book|title = Cutting Code: Software and Sociality|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=083BUgMnLKQC|publisher = Peter Lang|date = 1 January 2006|isbn = 9780820478234|first = Adrian|last = Mackenzie}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Futures Past: Thirty Years of Arts Computing|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=8z_GXxkyDn4C|publisher = Intellect Books|date = 1 January 2007|isbn = 9781841501680|first = Anna|last = Bentkowska-Kafel|first2 = Trish|last2 = Cashen|first3 = Hazel|last3 = Gardiner}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Violence and the Limits of Representation|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=oWujVgoWfFwC|publisher = Palgrave Macmillan|date = 31 May 2013|isbn = 9781137296917|first = Graham|last = Matthews|first2 = Sam|last2 = Goodman}}</ref> and co-founding the runme.org software art repository with [[Olga Goriunova]], [[Amy Alexander]] and [[Alexei Shulgin]] in 2003, which received an honorary mention in the Prix [[Ars Electronica]] netvision category in 2004.
Alex McLean performs as a solo artist under the moniker Yaxu and is also a member of the live coding bands [[Slub (band)|Slub]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Armitage|first=Tom|title=Making music with live computer code|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2009-09/25/making-music-with-live-computer-code-|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> and [[Canute (band)]]. He has also collaborated with Kate Sicchio in combining live coding and live choreography.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Squires|first1=Paul|url=https://www.imperica.com/en/in-conversation-with/in-conversation-with-kate-sicchio-and-alex-mclean|title=In conversation with Kate Sicchio and Alex McLean|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref>
During 2016, McLean is sound artist in residence at the [[Open Data Institute]], as part of the [[Sound and Music]] embedded programme.<ref>{{ Cite web | url=http://soundandmusic.org/projects/embedded-alex-mclean-chosen-odis-sound-artist-residence | accessdate=26 January 2016 | title=Alex McLean chosen as ODI's sound artist in residence}}</ref>
==Discography==

Collins | company = [[Cartoon Network Studios]] | distributor = | released = {{Start date|2007|8|10}} | website = }} '''''Ben 10: Secret of the Omnitrix''''' is an animated [[science fiction film]] based on the American [[animated television series]] ''[[Ben 10 (2005 TV series)|Ben 10]]''. It aired on August 10, 2007, in the United States and on October 22, 2007, in the UK. During the week-long special "Ben 10 week" in April 2008, it was revealed that this movie serves as the official finale to the series even though it was aired months before the last eight episodes and the last one which was non-canon of the fourth season. It was released to DVD on May 20, 2008 exclusively at [[Walmart]] stores. However, neither of the alternate versions were on the disc, merely the original with Heatblast, but the fourth season DVD contains all four versions, plus the pop up trivia version. The film comprises the three episodes of the fourth season, and is a finale to the series canonically. == Plot == {{plot|date=January 2018}} During a battle with Dr. Animo, Ben Tennyson's destruction of the scientist's "DNA bomb" accidentally sets off a self-destruct protocol in the [[Ben 10 (TV series)#The Omnitrix|Omnitrix]]. Its activation alerts Tetrax Shard, a bounty hunter and ally, who travels with his alien slime -like pilot Gluto to Earth in order to retrieve Ben. He explains the situation to Ben, who hasn't figured out the meaning of the countdown. He leaves Gwen and Grandpa Max behind, not wanting the latter to be recognized during their trip, but Gwen sneaks on board anyway. Using the advanced medical equipment on board his ship, Tetrax finds the DNA signature of the Omnitrix's creator, Azmuth, and tracks him to a prison facility called Incarcecon. During the journey, Tetrax hopes Ben would stop being a hero when the Omnitrix stop the countdown and Azmuth would shut it up for good. Ben is upset that he'll never be a hero again. After staging a breakout, they free a female Chimera Sui Generis (Vilgax's species) named Myaxx, who is Azmuth's assistant; she had switched her [[DNA]] signature for Azmuth's when he refused to give her credit for helping to create the Omnitrix. Myaxx is also unable to disarm the self-destruct, which will not only kill Ben, but most of the universe's inhabitants, including Earth itself, but Myaxx knows how to find Azmuth, and leads them to Xenon, where he is currently hiding on. However, Ben's archenemy Vilgax, who has escaped the Null Void, also picks up on the Omnitrix's self-destruct signal, picks up Sixsix, one of Tetrax's rivals, and starts tracking Ben. While attempting to reach Azmuth, they are attacked by Vilgax. Ben is ultimately successful in repelling the attack, though Gluto is supposedly killed in the conflict while protecting Gwen, who blames Ben. Tetrax's ship crashes on Azmuth's homeworld. As they enter his mountain fortress, they are attacked by a group of Florauna (Wildvine's species) which capture Gwen. Ben is depressed, and blames himself. As Ben reluctantly proceeds with Tetrax and Myaxx down towards Azmuth's lair, Tetrax empathizes with Ben, revealing his origins of how working for Vilgax cost him his whole planet and everyone he's ever cared for. Tracking down Azmuth to a sealed secondary laboratory, Ben asks him to shut down the Omnitrix, but Azmuth, unconcerned about anything around him, refuses. Angry, Ben breaks down the wall with Cannonbolt and attacks him, revealing Azmuth to be an old, curmudgeonly Galvan (Grey Matter's species) hiding inside a large mechanical suit. As far as Azmuth is concerned, the whole universe deserves whatever it gets for misusing the Omnitrix. He tells them the Omnitrix was designed to be the ultimate device of peace and understanding. Everyone else made it a problem, only seeing it as the ultimate weapon. Vilgax, having recovered from his earlier defeat, leads a massive attack on Azmuth's mountain fortress. During the fight, Gwen and Gluto reappear, Ben runs over to hug Gwen and Gluto having regenerated from some leftover material that splashed on Gwen's clothes and subsequently helping her to escape. Ben's actions during the battle renew Azmuth's faith in the universe, so he repairs the Omnitrix and he tells Ben that everyone thought Ben would never be hero if he stop the countdown, but Azmuth never said Ben would stop being a hero when the countdown stop. He gives Ben a brand-new form to use: [[List of Ben 10 aliens#Way Big|Way Big]], a skyscraper-sized alien modeled after [[Ultraman]], who easily repels Vilgax's army of drones and angrily tosses the villain into space. With the threat over, Ben offers to return the Omnitrix to Azmuth, who is leaving Xenon with Myaxx. Azmuth, however, sees Ben as the best place for the Omnitrix to be, both because he is technically fulfilling its original intention and because the Omnitrix attracts trouble simply by virtue of its existence. Tetrax returns Ben and Gwen to Earth, leaving Ben with a new hoverboard to replace the one Ben destroyed during his battle with Animo. Tetrax is disappointed that Ben will continue being a hero and he begins to accept Ben. The Tennysons' hope of having a normal day of recreation, however, is dashed by a newsflash of '[[zombie]]s' attacking the [[shopping mall|mall]], leading them to rush to the rescue calling this a normal life for the Tennysons. === Alternate versions === ''Ben 10: Secret of the Omnitrix'' was released three different times, each featuring a different alien destroying Animo's DNA bomb. Ben uses Heatblast in the first, a new form called Eye Guy in the second, and XLR8 in the third. A fourth version (actually a special version of the Ditto edition) released on the Ben 10 4th season and the movie's DVDs features trivia inserts inserted in the film. ==Voice Cast== * [[Tara Strong]] {{Infobox Olympic bid|2022|Winter| | main = yes |logo = Beijing 2022 Olympic bid logo.png |logo-size = 200px |map = |caption = |winner = Beijing |votes1 = 44 |runner-up = Almaty |votes2 = 40 |Paralympics = Yes |1stBid = 14 November 2013 |2ndBid = |shortlist = 7 July 2014 |decision = July 31, 2015 |notes = }} A total of six '''bids''' were initially submitted '''for the [[2022 Winter Olympics]]'''. Four of the bids were subsequently withdrawn by 1 October 2014, citing either the high costs of hosting the Games or the lack of local support, leaving [[Almaty, Kazakhstan]] and [[Beijing, China]] as the only two remaining candidate cities.{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3462070/olympics-winter-2022/|title=Why Nobody Wants to Host the 2022 Winter Olympics|date=3 October 2014|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=20 September 2015|first=Lisa|last=Abend}} [[Beijing]] was then elected as the host city at the [[128th IOC Session]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]], on 31 July 2015. ==Bidding calendar== On 3 October 2012, the IOC announced in a letter to the [[National Olympic Committee|NOCs]] the bidding calendar for the 2022 Winter Olympics:{{cite news|url=http://www.olympic.org/content/the-ioc/bidding-for-the-games/current-bid-process-2022/|title= 2022 Olympic Winter Games Current bid process |format=}} * 3 October 2012 – First information circular letter to NOCs * 6 June 2013 – IOC officially invites bid applicants from NOCs and publishes the 2022 Applicant City Questionnaire{{cite news|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/ioc-opens-bids-for-2022-olympic-winter-games-yog-2020/200340|title=IOC opens bids for 2022 Olympic Winter Games, YOG 2020|work=olympic.org|publisher=International Olympic Committee|date=6 June 2013}}{{cite web|url= http://www.olympic.org/Documents/Host_city_elections/2022_Candidature_Acceptance_Procedure.pdf |title=2022 candidature acceptance procedure }} – ''International Olympic Committee'' * 14 November 2013 – Deadline for NOCs to submit the name of an applicant city * 4–6 December 2013 – Applicant city seminar at the IOC headquarters in [[Lausanne]], Switzerland * 7–23 February 2014 – Olympic Winter Games Observer Programme * 14 March 2014 – Submission of the application file * 7 July 2014 – Selection of candidate cities by the IOC Executive Board * 7 January 2015 – Submission of candidature files and guarantees * 14–18 February 2015 in Almaty – IOC Evaluation Commission visits * 24–28 March 2015 in Beijing – IOC Evaluation Commission visits * 1–2 June 2015 – Evaluation Commission report * 9–10 June 2015 – Candidate City briefing to IOC members * 31 July 2015 – Host city election at the [[128th IOC Session|128th]] [[IOC Session]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] ==Candidate cities venues list== Note that the selected candidate cities have slightly changed venues plan in the final proposal to the IOC. Almaty moved technical alpine skiing events from [[Shymbulak]] to Tau, and completely removed both Kok Zhaylau and Ak-Bulak ski resorts, previously proposed for snowboarding and freestyle skiing events. Beijing dropped both Taiwu and Wanlong ski resorts, and proposed hosting snowboarding and freestyle skiing events in the two venues (A and B) in Genting Snow Park.

==Candidate cities overview== On 15 November 2013, the IOC announced the list of the six applicant cities.{{cite news|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/rising-interest-in-olympic-winter-games-as-six-cities-bid-to-host-2022-games/217175|title=Rising interest in Olympic Winter Games as six cities bid to host 2022 Games|work=olympic.org|publisher=International Olympic Committee|date=15 November 2013}} On 7 July 2014, the IOC announced that there were three remaining applicant cities that would move on to the candidate phase; these were Almaty, Beijing and Oslo. On 1 October 2014, Oslo withdrew its application after one of the country's governing political parties [[Conservative Party (Norway)|Høyre]] decided not to support the application.[https://www.si.com/more-sports/2014/10/01/norway-rejects-2022-winter-olympics "Norway government rejects 2022 Winter Olympics bid"], from ''Sports Illustrated'' 1 October 2014 The remaining two candidate cities were therefore Almaty and Beijing.{{cite news|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/first-ioc-executive-board-meeting-under-president-bach/218358|title=First IOC Executive Board meeting under President Bach|publisher=International Olympic Committee|work=olympic.org|date=10 December 2013}}{{cite news|title=Five bid cities submit application files to host 2022 Olympic Winter Games|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/five-bid-cities-submit-application-files-to-host-2022-olympic-winter-games/227355|work=olympic.org|publisher=International Olympic Committee|date=14 March 2014}} Both of the candidate cities suggested hosting the Games between February 4–20, 2022. The Paralympics will be held from March 4–13. While another city suggested hosting the Games between February 11–27, 2022. The Paralympics will be held from March 11–20. ===Almaty=== {| class="infobox" style="width: 20em;" |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#0084c9; color:#fff;"| Almaty |- |colspan="2" style="background:#e8b030; text-align: center;"| '''[[Almaty bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics|Overview]]''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; padding:0.5em;"| |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#000; color:#fff;"| Details |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#009e49; color:#fff;"| Votes | valign="top"| 40 |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#e5053a; color:#fff;"| Country | valign="top"| {{FlagIOC|KAZ}} |} {{main article|Almaty bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics}} Since 2011, the [[National Olympic Committee of the Republic of Kazakhstan]] has been considering a bid for the 2022 games in [[Almaty]], the former longtime [[capital city]] and still the largest city and financial centre of the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/winter_olympic_bids/future_winter_bids/1216135536.html |title=Kazakhstan Considers 2022 Winter Games Bid |publisher=GamesBids.com |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=14 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114010311/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/winter_olympic_bids/future_winter_bids/1216135536.html |archivedate=14 November 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.aroundtherings.com/articles/view.aspx?id=42105|title=Oslo Talks Public Support; Toronto Searches for Mascot; FEI Ousts Guadalajara|work=aroundtherings.com}}{{cite web|url=http://en.tengrinews.kz/kazakhstan_news/Kazakhstan-to-bid-for-2022-winter-Olympic-Games--445/|title=Kazakhstan to bid for 2022 winter Olympic Games|publisher=En.tengrinews.kz|date=28 March 2011|accessdate=14 November 2013}} Kazakhstan hosted the [[2011 Asian Winter Games]]. Almaty will host [[2017 Winter Universiade]]. The current Kazakh capital [[Astana]] considered to joint bid with Almaty but the idea was later declined. On 17 August 2013, Almaty announced they were bidding for the 2022 Games.[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/winter_olympic_bids/future_winter_bids/1216136727.html Almaty Bids For 2022 Winter Olympic Games] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006122431/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/winter_olympic_bids/future_winter_bids/1216136727.html |date=October 6, 2014 }} Under the slogan "Keeping it Real", Almaty has emphasized her traditional winter setting with tall mountains and plenty of natural snow coverage as well as compactness — most venues are within half an hour's travel through Alpine scenery.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/almaty-offers-traditional-winter-setting-in-2022-olympic-bid/2015/07/28/d2de145a-3505-11e5-b835-61ddaa99c73e_story.html Almaty offers traditional winter setting in 2022 Olympic bid], [[Washington Post]], 2015/7/28[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jul/26/almaty-2022-winter-olympic-bid-at-a-glance/?page=all Almaty 2022 Winter Olympic bid at a glance], [[Washington Times]], 2015/7/26 Presenting Kazakhstan's bid at the final event in Kuala Lumpur, Prime Minister of Kazakhstan [[Karim Massimov]] made a powerful speech with a key message that Almaty was "not a risk choice for 2022", but "a golden opportunity to prove that smaller advancing nations can successfully host the winter games". He called to the OCI core values saying that letting Almaty host the Games was "a golden opportunity to showcase the real long-term power of Olympic legacy for a region that has never hosted the Games".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v6kx0YUXJGg Speech made by Karim Massimov before the final voting in Kuala Lumpur on July 31] In the final voting Almaty lost to Beijing by only 4 votes. ===Beijing=== {| class="infobox" style="width: 20em;" |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#0084c9; color:#fff;"| Beijing |- |colspan="2" style="background:#e8b030; text-align: center;"| '''[[Beijing bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics|Overview]]''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; padding:0.5em;"| |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#000; color:#fff;"| Details |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#009e49; color:#fff;"| Votes | valign="top"| 44 |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#e5053a; color:#fff;"| Country | valign="top"| {{FlagIOC|CHN}} |} {{main article|Beijing bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics}} On 5 November 2013, the [[Chinese Olympic Committee]] announced that it would submit a bid for [[Beijing]] to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. Beijing (where the indoor ice sports and the ceremonies would take place), was the host city of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. [[Zhangjiakou]] would host the outdoor snow events.{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/winter-olympics/2022/1016809-beijing-and-zhangjiakou-launch-a-joint-bid-to-host-the-2022-winter-olympic-games|title=Beijing and Zhangjiakou launch joint bid to host 2022 Winter Olympic Games|work=insidethegames.biz}} Before the final voting in Kuala Lumpur Beijing's bid was presented by Yang Lan, a renowned former CCTV host, who said sports and fitness were becoming a new fashion trend in China. In her speech she focused on China's economy and its ability to support every commitment it made "protecting long time financial viability and the reputation of the Games".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0uW5JT2_G2o Speech of Yang Lan before the final voting in Luala Lumpur on July 31] ===Oslo=== {| class="infobox" style="width: 20em;" |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#0084c9; color:#fff;"| Oslo |- |colspan="2" style="background:#e8b030; text-align: center;"| '''[[Oslo bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics|Overview]]''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; padding:0.5em;"| |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#000; color:#fff;"| Details |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#009e49; color:#fff;"| Votes | valign="top"| Withdrew bid |- ! style="text-align:center; background:#e5053a; color:#fff;"| Country | valign="top"| {{FlagIOC|NOR}} |} {{main article|Oslo bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics}} On 6 November 2013, the [[Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports]] announced that Oslo would be submitted as the Norwegian candidate for the 2022 Winter Olympic Games. Oslo last hosted the [[1952 Winter Olympics]], and Norway last hosted the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer]].{{cite news|last=Mackay|first=Duncan|title=Exclusive: Oslo confirm they will bid for 2022 Winter Olympics and Paralympics|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/winter-olympics/2022/1016831-exclusive-oslo-confirm-they-will-bid-for-2022-winter-olympics-and-paralympics|accessdate=6 November 2013|date=6 November 2013}} On 1 October 2014 the [[Conservative Party (Norway)|Conservative Party]] decided that they would not support a bid for the games citing costs and lack of public support.{{Cite news|title = Oslo Withdraws Bid to Host 2022 Winter Games, Citing Cost|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/02/sports/oslo-withdraws-bid-for-2022-olympics-citing-high-cost-of-games.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2014-10-01|access-date = 2015-09-18|issn = 0362-4331|first = Lynn|last = Zinser}} A vast number of polls were conducted, and since April 2014 support had varied between 24% and 37%.{{Cite web|title = OL-stemningen|url = http://www.minervanett.no/ol-stemningen/|website = Minerva|accessdate = 2015-09-18}} The days leading up to the deliberation in the Conservative Party had consisted of a series of negative developments for the bid. Those negative developments included the [[Centre Party (Norway)|Centre Party]] saying no through a grass root vote,{{Cite web|title = Senterpartiet sier nei til OL i Oslo 2022 - Senterpartiet|url = http://www.senterpartiet.no/meny-forside/senterpartiet-sier-nei-til-ol-i-oslo-2022-article84533-12919.html|website = www.senterpartiet.no|accessdate = 2015-09-18|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160204172514/http://www.senterpartiet.no/meny-forside/senterpartiet-sier-nei-til-ol-i-oslo-2022-article84533-12919.html|archivedate = 2016-02-04|df = }} a poll showing that even within the [[Norwegian Confederation of Sports]] the majority of members opposed the bid,{{Cite web|title = Idrettsmedlemmer splittet om OL|url = http://www.nrk.no/norge/idrettsmedlemmer-splittet-om-ol-1.11959889|accessdate = 2015-09-18|last = NRK}} an external revision which clarified that the newly suggested cheaper budget was unrealistic{{Cite web|title = Billig-OL dyrere enn antatt|url = http://www.nettavisen.no/na24/billig-ol-dyrere-enn-antatt/8492490.html|accessdate = 2015-09-18|last = NTB}} and public scrutiny on [[IOC]]´s 7000 pages of demands.{{Cite web|title = The Olympics that no-one wants?|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/winter-olympics/29455789|accessdate = 2015-09-18}} Norway rejected the olympic committee's application for government funding to hold the event in Norway after the private organisation IOC made a large number of demands which caused a scandal in Norway. The demands notably included "diva-like demands for luxury treatment" for the IOC members themselves, such as special lanes on all roads only to be used by IOC members and a cocktail reception at the Royal Palace with drinks paid for by the royal family. Several commentators pointed out that such demands were unheard of in a western democracy; ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' described the IOC as a "notoriously ridiculous organization run by grifters and hereditary aristocrats."[http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2014/10/02/ioc_demands_oslo_drops_bid_after_over_the_top_list_of_requirements.html The IOC Demands That Helped Push Norway Out of Winter Olympic Bidding Are Hilarious], Slate[http://nationalpost.com/sports/olympics/ioc-reportedly-made-some-ridiculous-demands-to-help-push-oslo-out-of-2022-winter-olympics-bidding IOC reportedly made some ridiculous demands to help push Oslo out of 2022 Winter Olympics bidding][https://www.vg.no/sport/ol-2022/ioc-krever-gratis-sprit-paa-stadion-og-cocktail-fest-med-kongen/a/23306598/ IOC krever gratis sprit på stadion og cocktail-fest med Kongen] == Applicant cities overview== *{{flagicon|POL}} '''[[Kraków]], Poland''' {{main article|Kraków bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics}} On 7 November 2013, the [[Polish Olympic Committee]] announced they submitted a bid to the IOC for the 2022 Winter Olympics, together with [[Zakopane]], Poland, and [[Jasná]], a village in central [[Slovakia]], near the Polish border.{{cite web|title=Polish Olympic Committee to Bid for 2022 Games|url=http://www.pkol.pl/pl/pages/news/6159|work=Polish Olympic Committee|accessdate=7 November 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/winter-olympics/2022/1016844-poland-and-slovakia-confirm-joint-bid-for-2022-winter-olympics-and-paralympics|title=Poland and Slovakia confirm joint bid for 2022 Winter Olympics and Paralympics|work=insidethegames.biz}} If the bid had been successful, it would have been the first time either Poland or Slovakia hosted the Stockholm previously hosted the [[1912 Summer Olympics]] and hosted [[Equestrian at the 1956 Summer Olympics|equestrian events]] of the [[1956 Summer Olympics]], but this was the first time the Swedish capital was bidding for the Winter Olympics. Also, it would have been the first city to host both the Summer Olympics and the Winter Olympics, but that honour went to Beijing. ==Voting results for the 2022 Winter Olympics and Paralympics== Beijing was selected as host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics and Winter Paralympics after beating Almaty by just four votes. Hiver|publisher=France 3|accessdate=1 August 2012}} *{{flagicon|FIN}} '''[[Tahko]], [[Kuopio]], and [[Helsinki]], Finland''' :During the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] in Vancouver, Jouko Purontakanen, the progresses. [[Stefan Wallin]], Finland's Minister for Culture and Sports, has also suggested that Finland should bid for the 2022 games with other Nordic countries after Finland's NOC discusses with them in Vancouver.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv3.fi/uutiset/kotimaa.shtml/arkistot/kotimaa/2010/02/1061522|title=Urheiluministeri Wallin haluaa talviolympialaiset Suomeen vuonna 2022 – MTV3.fi – Uutiset – Kotimaa|publisher=MTV3.fi|accessdate=5 March 2011}} Nothing followed from these suggestions: the heightening of Tahko hill did not progress since 2010 due to environmental concerns,{{cite web|url=http://www.supertahko.fi/index.php |title=SuperTahko website |accessdate=15 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112052312/http://www.supertahko.fi/index.php |archivedate=12 November 2013 |df= }} and no Nordic countries indicated an interest to bid with Finland since the discussions in Vancouver. *{{flagicon|GER}} '''[[Munich]], Germany''' :Following Munich's [[Munich bid for the 2018 Winter Olympics|failed bid]] to host the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], plans for a second attempt were made. On 30 September 2013, ''[[Deutscher Olympischer Sportbund]]'' (the German [[National Olympic Committee]]) announced its intention to submit a bid for Munich to host the 2022 Winter Olympics.{{cite news|title=Olympia 2022: DOSB spricht sich für Münchner Bewerbung aus|url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/sonst/olympia-2022-a-925396.html|accessdate=30 September 2013|newspaper=[[Spiegel Online]]|date=30 September 2013|language=German}} However, these plans were cancelled on 10 November 2013 when a majority of residents in the Munich area opposed the bid in referendums held in Munich, [[Garmisch-Partenkirchen]] and the Bavarian districts of [[Berchtesgadener Land]] and [[Traunstein District|Traunstein]] (where the competitions would have taken place).{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/winter-olympics/2022/1016892-munich-citizens-against-bid-for-2022-winter-olympics-and-paralympics|title=Munich citizens vote against bid for 2022 Winter Olympics and Paralympics|publisher=insidethegames.biz|accessdate=10 November 2013}} In each locality, a majority had voted against bidding: 51.2% in Munich, 51.6% in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, 54.0% in Berchtesgadener Land, and 59.7% in Traunstein.{{cite journal|title=So hat München abgestimmt|journal=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]|date=10 November 2013|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/muenchen/nein-zu-olympia-so-hat-muenchen-abgestimmt-1.1815340|language=German|accessdate=11 November 2013}} Opponents pointed to the high costs for hosting the Olympics, environmental issues, and criticism of commercialization of sports, particularly [[International Olympic Committee#Controversies|the IOC]].{{cite web|title=Für München - Gegen Olympia 2022|url=http://www.nolympia.de/|publisher=Nolympia|accessdate=11 November 2013}} :In order to address concerns voiced about the 2018 bid, the 2022 Games would have been located at four different places. Only Alpine Skiing and Ski Jumping competitions would have been held at Garmisch-Partenkirchen (the host city of the [[1936 Winter Olympics]]), whilst Nordic Skiing and Biathlon events would have taken place at existing facilities at [[Ruhpolding]], thus minimizing the land use. The [[Königssee bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track]] would have become another important venue. Indoor ice skating events and ski/snowboard half-pipe competitions would have been held at the [[Olympiapark, Munich|Olympiapark]] in Munich, the main site of the [[1972 Summer Olympics]]; and the [[Olympic Stadium (Munich)|Olympic Stadium]] would have been used for the opening and closing ceremonies.{{cite news|title=Der Bürgerentscheid wird zur großen Olympia-Hürde|url=https://www.welt.de/sport/olympia/article120554054/Der-Buergerentscheid-wird-zur-grossen-Olympia-Huerde.html|accessdate=25 October 2013|newspaper=[[Die Welt]]|date=1 October 2013|language=German}} *{{flagicon|NZL}} '''[[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]]—[[Christchurch]], New Zealand''' :Queenstown, New Zealand's main winter sports centre, has toyed with the idea of bidding for hosting rights of the Winter Olympics in the past, notably a 2007 report suggesting a bid (co-hosting with [[Dunedin]]) for the 2018 games. A proposal to bring the games to the [[Southern Hemisphere]] for the first time in 2022, to be jointly held in Queenstown and Christchurch, has been mooted by a private group, but does not have general support among the country's Olympians and is seen as unlikely to proceed.{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/other-sports/4547035/New-Zealand-Winter-Olympics-bid-ambitious|title=New Zealand Winter Olympics bid 'ambitious'|publisher=stuff.co.nz|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=9 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10703330|title=South Island 'couldn't cope' with Winter Olympics|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=9 September 2013}} *{{flagicon|ROU}} '''[[Brașov]] and [[Prahova Valley]], Romania''' :The mayor of [[Brașov]], [[George Scripcaru]], said in September 2011 that his city would be interested to bid if the [[2013 European Youth Winter Olympic Festival]] is a success.{{cite web|url=http://bzb.ro/index.php?page_name=stire_detalii&id_stire=66942|title=Dacă FOTE 2013 iese bine, urmează Jocurile Olimpice de Iarnă la Braşov|accessdate=11 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111125024849/http://www.bzb.ro/index.php?page_name=stire_detalii&id_stire=66942|archivedate=25 November 2011|df=}} In 2007, former Romanian Prime Minister [[Călin Popescu Tăriceanu]] announced that the country was considering a bid for the [[Prahova Valley]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-arhiva-1062533-tariceanu-vrea-olimpiada-din-2022.htm|title=Tariceanu vrea Olimpiada din 2022! – Arhiva noiembrie 2007|publisher=HotNews.ro|accessdate=5 March 2011}} Instead of bidding for 2022, Brașov's mayor, George Scripcaru, announced in November 2013 that Brașov will be bidding to host the [[2020 Winter Youth Olympics]]. *{{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Barcelona]], Spain''' {{further|Plans for Winter Olympics held in Barcelona}} :[[Barcelona]], which hosted the [[1992 Summer Olympics]], considered a bid for the 2022 Olympics, but on 25 October 2013, mayor [[Xavier Trias]] announced that "the conditions" would not exist yet. After the decision on 11 August 2011 a feasibility study for the Games was announced including the possibility to extend ice events to [[Zürich]]. The organizers decided during a session on 22 December 2011 to go forward with "St. Moritz 2022" as the official corporate name of the bid.{{cite web|url=http://www.suedostschweiz.ch/politik/st-moritz-hat-die-besseren-chancen-sich-durchzusetzen|title=Politik: «St. Moritz hat die besseren Chancen, sich [[File:Lepida-Celsa - Calle con Insula II a la derecha.jpg|thumb|Street on Insula II]] '''Celsa''' was an important pre-Roman and Roman city located near the modern town of [[Velilla de Ebro]].
Recent excavations have brought to light many rich private and public buildings which give a glimpse of its former grandeur.
==History== Celsa was originally an Iberian settlement, called ''Kelse'', of the [[Ilergetes]] tribe. It was located in the middle reaches of the River Ebro at a privileged position on the natural route from the coast to the peninsular. It was sited on terraces rising from the river and dominating a strategic ford.
From the mid-second to the first half of the first century BC, Kelse coined its own currency with representations of winged victories, Hercules and Venus and this is the main documentation of the city. [[File:Kelse sII-IaC.JPG|thumb|Bronze coin minted in Kelse in the 2nd century BC, showing its name in the Iberian language]]
It later had the only stone bridge over the upper Ebro <ref>Geography, Strabo, Volume 1, 10</ref> located in Velilla de Ebro, where remains of a bridge were reported in the 19th c.
[[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (triumvir)|Marcus Emilius Lepidus]], governor of [[Hispania Citerior]], founded a [[Colonia (Roman)|colony]] here in 44 BC with discharged veterans of the legions, who each received a plot of land to cultivate and the grant of Roman citizenship.<ref>Lepidus: The Tarnished Triumvir by Richard D. Weigel</ref> It was known as ''Colonia Celsa Lepida'', the highest rank of Roman city and one of the only two colonies in [[Aragon]] with [[Caesaraugusta]]. The new town occupied an area of about 44 ha. and played a key role as communications centre via [[Tarraco]] (Tarragona). The population eventually numbered about 4,000.
The settlement was soon renamed ''Colonia Victrix Iulia Celsa'' because Lepidus was removed from political office and exiled in 36 BC by Augustus, Caesar's successor.<ref>The Oxford Classical Dictionary; Simon Hornblower, Antony Spawforth, Esther Eidinow</ref> Celsa experienced a period of great splendour, but it was brief and from the time of [[Nero]] it began to wane. The reason for its decline is likely to be due to economic and administrative changes resulting from the creation of a new and thriving colony in the area, Caesaraugusta, which monopolised the main trade flows.
==Site== [[File:Lepida-Celsa - Mosaico en la Casa de los Delfines 03.jpg|thumb|Mosaic in the House of the Dolphins]]
Whole neighbourhoods have been brought to light with paved streets and blocks of houses of several floors arranged around courtyards, in Roman fashion, and rooms decorated with mosaics and paintings are numerous. Commercial establishments such as warehouses, shops, a market and a bakery can be seen.
Roman architects carefully designed the street plan around the terraced slopes so that the streets evacuated rainwater into the [[Ebro]] because, unlike other Roman cities, it had no drains. For this reason the main arteries of the city are parallel and perpendicular to the river.
Excavations have also unearthed remains of several residential buildings of great interest, among which are the Houses of the Dolphin and of [[Hercules]], both with beautiful and important wall paintings.
===House of Hercules===
[[File:Hércules con la clava y jabalí de Erimanto.jpg|thumb|Fresco from the House of Hercules: Hercules and the [[Erymanthian boar]]]] This latter house, of enormous dimensions, inaugurated the use of the Tuscan [[atrium (architecture)|atrium]] in Celsa, one of the earliest types of italic-style house. Two stages can be seen in this house; the first (from the founding of the colony) centred around the Tuscan atrium and the second after the addition of the arcaded courtyard to the north, in the reign of [[Augustus]]. Rainwater collected in the [[impluvium]] of the atrium and was stored in a giant water tank located under room 29. The mosaic floors are of great beauty, especially in room 1 which also had walls adorned with paintings of the second [[Pompeian Styles|Pompeian style]], displaying several episodes of the labours of Hercules which gave its name to the house. The arcaded courtyard gave access to well-designed rooms for a peaceful and private life.
===House of the Dolphin=== The House of the Dolphin is so named after the beautiful dolphins that decorate the mosaic floors. It was altered several times after combining the two houses that the initially occupied the ''[[Insula (Roman city)|insula]]'', or block, up to the time of [[Claudius]] in 54 AD. This great mansion took shape in the first decade of the 1st c. AD built around two spaces. The first part (rooms 1-14) corresponds to the public area and private rooms of the family; the second (15-22) is organised around an open courtyard with various rooms dedicated to services and slaves.
===Other Buildings=== The locations of possible temples, the theatre, the [[Forum (Roman)|forum]], major cisterns, springs, cemeteries and other public buildings have been identified. The theatre lies below the San José sanctuary where traces of the ''[[scaenae frons]]'' (stage) walls and tiers of seats (''[[cavea]]'') have been found.
Many small objects as lamps, Pompeian red slip dishes, Iberian ceramics, etc., as well as small bronzes, sculptural remains, coins and small pieces of jewellery are also preserved. A nearby museum displays many of the finds.<ref>http://www.museodezaragoza.es/exposiciones/exposicion-permanente-colonia-celsa-velilla-de-ebro-zaragoza/</ref>
==References== <references />
==Sources and further reading== *Holland, Tom, Rubicon: The Triumph and Tragedy of the Roman Republic, Abacus, 2004, {{ISBN|0-349-11563-X}}, 316. *http://www.turismodezaragoza.es/provincia/patrimonio/romano/colonia-lepida-celsa-velilla.html

Dower|title=Embracing Defeat: Japan in the Wake of World War II|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hae0dC_NaiUC&pg=PA407|year=2000|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-32027-5|pages=407–}}</ref> It exercised considerable influence over the operation and administration of the [[Occupation of Japan|American Occupation of Japan]] after [[World War II]]. <ref name="Takemae2003">{{cite book|author=Eiji Takemae|title=Allied Occupation of Japan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ba5hXsfeyhMC&pg=PA167|year=2003|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-0-8264-1521-9|pages=167–}}</ref>
